author: m.kalinin
content:
Cool. I have mentioned that we will be operating in a time restricted environment after the Merge. And resource exhaustion attacks may shift beacon block propagation time and thus impact on consensus. If we assume the attack scenario leading to 24 seconds block propagation delay (2 slots) due to high execution time then we'd miss `2/3` of blocks worth of slots. Though, this might look severe but recent accident with deposit data voting caused `~3/4` blocks missed in epoch (https://beaconcha.in/epoch/32304) without preventing finality showed that the beacon chain is pretty resilient to this kind of attacks. But anyway attacks leading to 50 seconds execution delays can start breaking finality and should be taken in account in the analysis.

I am curious about potential attack vectors that could be exploited to increase execution time significantly. Obviously, there are precompiles (some edge cases) and mostly state access. But since we have snapshots providing `O(1)` state access time during the execution, I suppose that the worst case for any state access including contract code reads should be computed out of reading and writing to storage slot or contract's code that doesn't exist; this is the worst case for DB engines as it doesn't hit any cached value (probably some bloom filters can handle it, idk). How do you think attack vectors look like with snapshots?

author: Deleted User
content: First of all, there is no O(1) access time usually, unless you keep the entire state in a very large hash map - which is impractical, because you cannot easily iterate over it, and it is hard to persist. So I would say it is more like O(log S), where S - size of the state. The coefficient there depends on whether State fits in RAM or not, for example. Currently, it can still fit in RAM on 64 Gb machines

author: Deleted User
content: Yes, bloom filters (or cuckoo filters because they allow deletions)  can efficiently protect against attacks based on querying mostly non-existent data

author: Deleted User
content: the attacks they are not protecting against are based on querying existing data. Yes, these attacks are much less potent, because such transaction has to essentially list all the accessed state locations in its input

author: Deleted User
content: you might consider it not to be an attack, but nevertheless, it is one of the things that determine the "safe" gas limit

author: holiman
content:
One funky type of bomb is a delete-bomb. On ropsten, there was a gigantic deletion (I cc:ed you <@456226577798135808> on a PR), which we totally didn't even notice when running in trie-mode. When we ran it in snapshot-mode, however, the selfdestruct of a massive account caused massive immediate db deletes, which were further problematic because of batching (memory blowup) and simultaneous iteration (iteration + deletion didn't mix well). 

So even the direct access model comes with problems.

author: m.kalinin
content: It would be great if we have an ability to evict malicious transactions that takes say `> 3s` of execution time. I am wondering whether this kind of protection would have any adverse effects.

author: holiman
content:
But my point in general on the ACD was more that sure: we can try to remove 'malicious' transaction. But from a miner perspective, 
a) If you've already spent 10s processing a tx, why not just include it? 
b) If you can construct a malicious tx which will take _you_ zero seconds to evaluate, but will take others `10s`, what's the downside of constructing such a block? The other miners will have to import it before they know it was malicious.

author: .vbuterin
content: Right, I think this is all defense-in-depth protection. Change the security model from "there are no DoS vulnerabilities" to "there are no DoS vulnerabilities OR there are very few malicious proposers"

author: m.kalinin
content: Right, but I am thinking of potential adverse effects that we could have by introducing no propagation rule. Probably, somebody wants to include this one transaction. So, less intrusive way would be still propagate but have an option for validators to sort out potentially malicious transactions that could result in the block they produce to be orphaned

author: m.kalinin

author: holiman
content: Yes, that makes sense. So my point was more that it doesn't _change_ the need for having constraints on gas. Defense in depth means that sure, we can  add  more perimeter stuff, but we still keep the same protections we had previously.

author: m.kalinin
content: Block proposers strictly follows the fork choice and they build on top of a block that is the head of the chain according to attestations received from the network. IMO, a self-protection excluding potentially malicious transactions from the payload that is being produced to allow for the block to be propagated in time and thus having chances to be included onchain should be sufficiently enough for block proposers. Even though such transactions are propagated in the network.

author: Deleted User
content: Are the attestations given once the validators have fully executed the block, or before it?

author: holiman
content: They already do this. I mean, until they've constructed a new block on top of `X`(where `X` is the malicious new potential head that just arrived), the backend-workers are still mining the old one

author: m.kalinin
content: They are made at a strict boundary which is 4 seconds throughout a slot. So, if a block produced in this slot hadn't been imported before this boundary attesters would vote for the current head e.g. a block produced in the previous slot.

author: Deleted User

author: m.kalinin
content: I think that for the beacon chain making malicious blocks on purpose is less of a problem than bombing network with malicious transactions and make everyone produce such blocks. This is why I see value in defending perimeter. And make it as less intrusive as possible, i.e. a self-protection mechanism preventing inclusion of potentially malicious transactions, would work. At the first glance I don't see any adverse effect of not propagating this kind of transactions but we would need to monitor these transactions in the network and having them propagated could also have positive effect.
